title: Albizia lebbeck
text:
Albizia lebbeck is a <a href="species">species</a> of "<a href="Albizia">Albizia</a>", native to <a href="Indomalayan%20realm">Indomalaya</a>, <a href="New%20Guinea">New Guinea</a> and <a href="Northern%20Australia">Northern Australia</a> and widely cultivated and <a href="naturalisation%20%28biology%29">naturalised</a> in other <a href="tropical">tropical</a> and <a href="subtropical">subtropical</a> regions. English names for it include lebbeck, lebbek tree, flea tree, frywood, koko and woman's tongue tree. The latter name is a play on the sound the seeds make as they rattle inside the pods. Being one of the most widespread and common species of "Albizia" worldwide, it is often simply called siris, though this name may refer to any locally common member of the <a href="genus">genus</a>.
Description.
It is a <a href="tree">tree</a> growing to a height of 18–30 m tall with a trunk 50 cm to 1 m in diameter. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are bipinnate, 7.5–15 cm long, with one to four pairs of pinnae, each pinna with 6–18 leaflets. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are white, with numerous 2.5–3.8 cm long stamens, and very fragrant. The <a href="fruit">fruit</a> is a <a href="legume">pod</a> 15–30 cm long and 2.5-5.0 cm broad, containing six to twelve <a href="seed">seed</a>s.
Name.
Mimosa speciosa as described by <a href="Nikolaus%20Joseph%20von%20Jacquin">Nikolaus Joseph von Jacquin</a> refers to "Albizia lebbeck". The "Mimosa speciosa" of <a href="Carl%20Peter%20Thunberg">Carl Peter Thunberg</a>, however, is "<a href="Albizia%20julibrissin">Albizia julibrissin</a>".
In <a href="Tamil%20Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a> , the tree is known as 'vaagai' as the ancient kings of the <a href="Sangam%20Age">Sangam Age</a> had worn the garland made by this flower to celebrate victory in battles , with the word 'vaagai' meaning 'victory' in <a href="Tamil%20language">Tamil</a>.
In the <a href="West%20Indies">West Indies</a> and certain parts of <a href="South%20America">South America</a> this tree is known as a 'Shak Shak Tree' because of the sound the seeds make in the pod.
Uses.
Its uses include environmental management, <a href="Fodder">forage</a>, medicine and wood. It is cultivated as a shade tree in <a href="North%20America">North</a> and <a href="South%20America">South America</a>. In India and Pakistan, the tree is used to produce <a href="timber">timber</a>. Wood from "Albizia lebbeck" has a density of 0.55-0.66 g/cm3 or higher.
Even where it is not native, some indigenous <a href="herbivore">herbivore</a>s are liable to utilize lebbeck as a food resource. For example, the <a href="greater%20rhea">greater rhea</a> ("Rhea americana") has been observed feeding on it in the <a href="cerrado">cerrado</a> of <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>.
Ethnobotany.
Lebbeck is an <a href="astringent">astringent</a>, also used by some cultures to treat boils, <a href="cough">cough</a>, to treat the <a href="human%20eye">eye</a>, <a href="flu">flu</a>, <a href="gingivitis">gingivitis</a>, <a href="human%20lung">lung</a> problems, pectoral problems, is used as a tonic, and is used to treat abdominal <a href="tumor">tumor</a>s. The bark is used medicinally to treat <a href="inflammation">inflammation</a>. This information was obtained via <a href="ethnobotany">ethnobotanical records</a>, which are a reference to how a plant is used by indigenous peoples, not verifiable, scientific or medical evaluation of the effectiveness of these claims. "Albizia lebbeck" is also <a href="psychoactive">psychoactive</a>..It is also very effective in migraine.
Taxonomy.
The <a href="Taxonomy%20%28biology%29">taxonomic</a> history of "A. lebbeck" is somewhat convoluted. It was originally described by <a href="Carl%20Linnaeus">Carl Linnaeus</a> as "Mimosa lebbeck". In its original description the "Mimosa lebbeck" was a large Acacia tree that grew in Egypt. <a href="George%20Bentham">George Bentham</a> placed the <a href="species">species</a> in its present <a href="genus">genus</a>, but other authors believed that the plant described by Linnaeus was the related "<a href="Albizia%20kalkora">Albizia kalkora</a>" as described by Prain (based on the "Mimosa kalkora" of <a href="William%20Roxburgh">William Roxburgh</a>), and erroneously referred to this species as "Albizia lebbeck". However, <a href="Francisco%20Manuel%20Blanco">Francisco Manuel Blanco</a> used "Mimosa lebbeck" to refer to "<a href="Albizia%20retusa">Albizia retusa</a>" ssp. "retusa". In addition, the <a href="specific%20name%20%28botany%29">specific epithet</a> is occasionally misspelled "lebbek".

Independently, there also exists a genus named "<a href="Lebeckia">Lebeckia</a>", whose range is restricted to South Africa. It is not related to "A. lebbeck", but a member of the <a href="Faboideae">Faboideae</a>, a different legume <a href="subfamily">subfamily</a>.
